awd_titl_txt: Network for Computational Nanotechnology - Hierarchical nanoMFG Node
awd_abstract_narration:
To become economically viable and accessible at large scales, nanomanufacturing critically depends on achieving control over complex process parameters and a thorough understanding of the underlying driving scientific phenomena. The goal of this collaborative effort will be to establish a Hierarchical Nanomanufacturing Node for computational tools development aimed at creating smart, model- and data-driven nanomanufacturing. By leveraging emerging advances in computing and cyberinfrastructure, the vision of this node is to simulate every step of the manufacturing process of a nano-enabled product.  Simulation tools developed will be optimized and tested for utility by stakeholders including researchers in nanotechnology and related industrial sectors. In addition, the impact of this 5-year activity on the nanomanufacturing industry will be critically assessed. The node will be part of the established Network for Computational Nanotechnology (NCN) Cyber Platform. 

The mission of the nanoMFG Node is to be the engine for design, simulation, planning, and optimization of highly relevant nano-manufacturing growth and patterning processes. Both working with the existing cyber framework (nanoHUB) and facilitating development of human resources that will broadly impact nanomanufacturing and nanotechnology are essential to this mission. To help achieve this mission, computational tools for nanomanufacturing aimed at multiscale theory, modeling, and simulation (TM&S) will be developed and broadly disseminated. The intellectual merit of this 5-year activity is the development of nanomanufacturing simulation tools, validated by experimental data, and integrated with data-driven uncertainty quantification. The framework for the effort is based on a layered computational tool infrastructure comprising the creation of the following: (1) nanoscale transport phenomena models, (2) process models, (3) uncertainty quantification framework, (4) application and empirical validation of process models, (5) tools for multiscale transport phenomena, and (6) tools for nanoscale self-assembly.   

Beyond nanomanufacturing, the burgeoning field of nanoscience will significantly benefit from free, open-source computational tools that have been validated by experiments. The collaboration will bring researchers, educators, industries, national labs, and high schools together to form a cohesive framework to advance nanoscience and resulting nanotechnologies, promote STEM education, and build the human resources necessary to make nanomanufacturing an economically viable engine for society. This will have several impacts on realizing the varied promises promulgated by nanotechnology as it pertains to: accelerating the high-tech economy, improving human health, and positively impacting an array of manufacturing industry domains including aviation, automotive, agricultural, construction machinery, and many others. Efforts to promote workforce diversification are tightly interwoven into this effort to both help increase participation from underrepresented groups and institutions and also to add to the richness of the tools being developed.  Fellowships will be competitively awarded annually to help train the next generation workforce not only on simulation and modeling tool development but also on the value of community building and sharing of resources and expertise, thus building a nationwide innovation ecosystem for economic development of the U.S. and its leadership worldwide.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
This award supported the creation of the Network for Computational Nanotechnology (NCN) Nanomanufacturing Node (nanoMFG), in order to enable the nanomanufacturing software tools, cyberinfrastructure, and data-sharing capabilities that are critical to transition basic nanomanufacturing research to commercial application. Nanomanufacturing refers to any manufacturing process that involves the production or manufacture of components with nanoscale features. It is an exciting and emerging area that involves:

  • developing production techniques that are economic, scalable, and produce viable yield;
  • controlling the precision of manufactured nanostructures;
  • establishing methods for control over nanoscale or atomic scale structure;
  • maintaining nanoscale properties during high-rate and high-volume production, and during the lifetime of the product.

The vision of nanoMFG has been to enable the collection and broad dissemination, via the NCN cyberplatform nanoHUB, of software-based tools, data, and information needed to understand and simulate the manufacturing process for nano-enabled products. 

     The node has foremost served as an infrastructure program that aims for community-driven software and tool development. Throughout the program, nanoMFG has put an emphasis on connecting researchers from academia, labs, and industry by the creation of scalable frameworks for integration and sharing of nanomanufacturing process data across the computational and experimental community. 

     The node has created online platforms that connect researchers who share an interest in a given nanomanufacturing process. The platforms are centered on integrating scientific/engineering expertise, hardware, infrastructure, models, and data to facilitate distributed experimentation and closing the loop between data and models, design and manufacturing, and ultimately research and education. One example is the Gr-ResQ (“graphene rescue”) database and tool suite (Figure 1). Gr-ResQ consists of a community database of synthesis recipes (shown on the right) and a set of software and analysis tools that help analyze the contents of the database. Users of the platform contribute data to the Gr-ResQ database, which may be searched and analyzed by other users to improve their synthesis recipes. The Gr-ResQ database currently contains 150 recipes, and has been accessed by users from multiple universities around the world.

     Over the course of the program, nanoMFG has deployed a suite of ~20 simulation tools that span across wide ranges of nanomanufacturing processes.  The tools address the modeling of both top-down and self-assembly nanomanufacturing processes including the mechanical, chemical, electrochemical and optical domains. The portfolio of tools developed include processes such as two-photon lithography, two-dimensional materials processes such as synthesis and exfoliation, nanoburnishing/nanomachining, and others. Uncertainty quantification frameworks -- using both standard approaches and machine learning -- have been combined with manufacturing tools to predict geometries with rigorous bounds. These tools have supported simulations for over 2500 unique tool users on nanoHUB to date.

     The program actively supported workforce training and development, through student-led software design, engagement of external participants through REU programs, the  nanoMFG fellowship program, and via published online content. nanoMFG sponsored two large community workshops with 100-200 participants each as well as several smaller workshops and seminars.  The node has also deployed educational content to nanoHUB, including courses, seminars, lectures, and tutorials. have published over 70 lectures, seminars, and tutorials on nanoHUB, three full semester courses on nanoHUB, and contributed 4 seminars to the NCN cyberplatform nanoHUB machine learning seminar series.

 


Last Modified: 12/31/2023
Modified by: Elif Ertekin

Image
  • The Network for Computational Nanotechnology Nanomanufacturing Nodes serves the emerging nanomanufacturing community by the creation reusable and scalable frameworks for integrating experimental/computational expertise and infrastructure with nanomanufacturing process data and computational models,
    Elif Ertekin
    Public Domain
    Elif Ertekin
    Data sharing platforms for emerging nanomanufacturing processes
